Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Does priming honesty elicit truthful disclosures from children regarding adult wrongdoing?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Children are often involved in the legal system as maltreatment victims, and their disclosure of adult wrongdoing is necessary to initiate effective legal responses and protect them from continued abuse. Current techniques for promoting children's honesty rely on explicit or direct requests that children tell the truth, such as eliciting a promise to tell the truth. However, the effectiveness of these techniques has differed across research studies. The proposed study will test the benefits of priming honesty (indirectly or non-consciously activating the goal of honesty) on children's disclosure of an adult's minor act of wrongdoing.

Children (ages 6-9) will individually participate in a first aid/safety event during which an adult (parent or stranger) will engage the children in play with forbidden puppets, supposedly "break" a puppet, and request that children keep it a secret. Before responding to event-related questions, children will be (1) primed for the goal of honesty by hearing a story laden with words about honesty, (2) asked to promise to tell the truth, or (3) reassured that many children play with the puppets and disclose the truth when asked. Then, children will be asked different types of questions about the event. Results will inform legal practitioners about whether priming, a simple, yet theoretically-based and novel technique for promoting children?s honesty, encourages children's true disclosures of adult wrongdoing. Results will also advance theory concerning children?s willingness to disclose wrongdoing committed by parents versus strangers, an important practical consideration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Children are often involved in the legal system as maltreatment victims, and their disclosures of adult wrongdoing are typically necessary to initiate effective legal and social service responses. However, for many reasons, children may delay disclosure or fail to disclose altogether. In part because the perpetrators in most maltreatment cases are individuals close to the children, reasons for nondisclosure may include familial or other external pressures and children's perceptions of the consequences of disclosure such as possible punishment. Currently available techniques for promoting children's honesty tend to rely on explicit or direct requests that children tell the truth, such as eliciting a promise to tell the truth (i.e., child-friendly version of “the oath”). However, because these explicit techniques focus on children’s conscious decisions to tell the truth, they may be especially influenced by external pressures and children’s expectations of the consequences of disclosure. Furthermore, children may be disqualified from testifying if they are unable or unwilling to promise to tell the truth or distinguish between truths and lies, for example.

The present study tested the benefits of priming honesty (indirectly or non-consciously activating the goal of honesty) on children's disclosure of an adult's minor act of wrongdoing. When it comes to encouraging children’s true disclosures of adult wrongdoing, we reasoned that “priming” may be more resistant to external pressures than explicit requests to tell the truth. 115 6- to 9-year-olds individually participated in a first aid/safety event during which an adult (the child’s mother or a stranger) engaged the children in play with forbidden puppets, supposedly “broke” a puppet, and requested that children keep the breakage a secret. Mothers and children also completed several measures assessing, for example, mother-child relationship quality and children’s trust in their parents. Before responding to event-related questions, children were (1) primed for the goal of honesty by hearing a story laden with words about honesty, (2) asked to promise to tell the truth, or (3) given no further instructions or information. Results revealed that children were more truthful to direct questions about the act of wrongdoing (such as to the question, “Did something bad happen?”) when they witnessed a stranger breaking the puppet rather than their mother. However, children’s truthful disclosures did not improve when a prime was used and did not differ by age. Exploratory analyses revealed that children with greater trust in their parents were less truthful about an adult’s act of wrongdoing (or more likely to keep the adult’s secret) than those with less trust in their parents.

Intellectual Merit

The findings advance our understanding of the factors influencing children’s willingness to disclose adult wrongdoing. Furthermore, by testing whether priming children for honesty encourages their truthful disclosures of another’s transgression, the present study extends the priming literature to the field of children’s eyewitness testimony.

Broader Impacts  

Identifying the factors that influence children’s disclosures of adult wrongdoing (e.g., identity of the perpetrator) has implications for the legal system. Investigators and other fact finders should be aware of this information when questioning children about maltreatment and interpreting their responses. Developing and refining methods for promoting children’s honesty may aid in the successful prosecution of perpetrators, protection of innocent suspects, and protection of children from maltreatment. This was the first experimental study to examine priming as an honesty promotion technique and thus provides potentially fruitful directions for future research. Numerous research assistants played key roles in the present study and received invaluable training and professional development. All of the research assistants were from groups traditionally underrepresented in science (i.e., ethnic minorities).
